Esdraelon

3 of 5: At the time of Jesus, the Jews had been persecuted for 700 years by the Babylonians, Assyrians, Persians, and now by the Greeks and Romans. Jews had been scattered and liv ed as captives in these nations. 
 
 However, today, we still see the Jews. We don't see Hittites, Perizzites, Ammonites, Assyrians, Persians, and Babylonians, adn other people who had been living at that time. Why? Because these people also got captured by other nations, intermarried and lost their national identity. 
 
 Why didn't this happen to the Jews? Because the things that made the Jews, Jews...the social structure that gave them their national identity....were unbelievably and fanatically important to them. They would pass this structures down to their children, celebrate them in meetings every Sabbath in the synagogues, and reinforce them with their rituals, because they knew if they didn't, there would soon be no Jews left. They would be assimilated into the cultures that captured them.
 
 And there is another very important reason why these structures were sacred: Because they believed that these structures were given to them by God. They believed that to abandon these institutions would be to risk their souls being damned to hell after death.
 
 Now a rabbi named Jesus appears from a lower-class region. He teaches for three years, gathers a following of lower and middle class people, gets in trouble with the authorities, gets crucified along with 30,000 other Jewish men who are executed during this time period. 
 
 But five weeks after he is crucified, ten thousand Jews are following Him, with more being converted daily, and claiming that He is the initiator of a new religion. And on top of this they are willing to give up, or alter all five of the social institutions taught to them by childhood and given to them by God and have such importance both socially and theologically. 
 
 Obviously something BIG was going on.

 Maybe, maybe not, I think not for many people used to think of first-century Judaism as a monolithic block, a solidly unified religion, from which Christianity split off as a new religion. In contrast, we now know that there were many different sub-groups within ancient Judaism, and that the early "Jesus Movement" was just one of many different Jewish groups. Moreover, the separation of Christianity from Judaism was not sudden, but happened gradually over several generations.
 
 Judaism at the time of Jesus was both unified and divided, much like Christianity is today. All Jews believed and practiced some core aspects of their religion (Monotheism, the Law of Moses, Circumcision, etc. -- see Covenants and Pillars of Ancient Judaism), but different Jewish groups debated and disagreed with each other about many details (expectations of the Messiah, ritual and purity laws, how to live under foreign domination, etc.). Similarly all Christians today agree on certain core items (Jesus is the Son of God, the NT has 27 books, etc.) but disagree on many details (the number of sacraments, forms of worship, role of faith and good works, etc.).
 
 To understand the separation of Christianity from Judaism, consider the analogy of parents and teenagers. Sometimes tensions within a family cause a separation; but do the parents throw the teenagers out, or do the teenagers run away from home? Sometimes it is the parents, sometimes the teens, and sometimes both! The religious situation in the first century was similar: sometimes a local group of Christians were ostracized or forced to leave Judaism; in other cases Christians chose to separate themselves from their Jewish heritage.
 
 Also, whose "fault" is it when parents and teenagers separate? Usually at least a little of both. Rarely do parents kick well-behaved children out of the house, and rarely do teens run away from parents who are not overly harsh or demanding. Similarly in the first century, certain factors on both sides caused those Jews who believed in Jesus as the Messiah (later called "Christians") to separate from the majority of Jews who thought believing in Jesus was wrong and potentially harmful to their religion.
 
 While some of the later writings of the NT show great hostility and nasty polemics between Jews and Christians, most of the arguments between Jesus and his contemporaries should be seen as inner-Jewish controversies. Not only did Jesus and his disciples disagree with and argue against various groups of other Jews, but these other groups also had major disagreements and arguments with each other on a whole variety of topics.
 
 To understand the New Testament properly, especially the life of Jesus as presented in the Gospels, one needs to learn about the wide variety of different Jewish groups that existed in the first century. Josephus, the first-century Jewish historian, describes three major Jewish groups and their "philosophies" or ways of life: Pharisees, Sadducees, and Essenes. He also mentions various other political and revolutionary groups of Jews active in the first century CE, especially during the first War against Rome.

 5But he was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our iniquities: the chastisement of our peace was upon him; and with his stripes we are healed. ISRAEL??
 
 6All we like sheep have gone astray; we have turned every one to his own way; and the LORD hath laid on him the iniquity of us all. ISRAEL??
 
 7He was oppressed, and he was afflicted, yet he opened not his mouth: he is brought as a lamb to the slaughter, and as a sheep before her shearers is dumb, so he openeth not his mouth.
  ISRAEL??
 
 8He was taken from prison and from judgment: and who shall declare his generation? for he was cut off out of the land of the living: for the transgression of my people was he stricken. ISRAEL??
